comment_text: Hey 'meiofauna', thanks for teaching me a new word that breaks the 'i before e except after c' rule.

Hi @SciShow, I'm the lead author of the meiofauna life on loggerhead paper in journal Diversity. so nice to see our work covered in this video...you did a great job explaining the results and main messages, thank you so much! the actual research is freely accessible here for those who are interested https://www.mdpi.com/1424-2818/12/5/203. For more A'Tuin references and Terry Pratchet quotes :-) LaboratoryNewsUK editor is a discworld fan and did a great story on it https://www.labnews.co.uk/article/2030727/the-truth-about-turtles

would love to see a gps map of some of the ones around my area in queensland, ive seen them all the way up creeks and rivers just chilling way up some narrow salt water creek. idk if its true or not but an old guy told me they go into the fresh water to clean up but could be thinking of something else.

Wow, wiping their shells clean is incredibly invasive if they actually did what was described here. That's bad science and terrible conservation, shame on them. Next years information will be specifically misleading if they retest these turtles. The only science they will achieve with those specimens in the future will be on the ability of a healthy, naturally biodiverse turtle shell to recover from a good scrubbing by humans. Garbage in, garbage out.

I'm curious if any of these meiofauna are beneficial or symbiotic to the turtle? I think there is every reason to believe that a healthy meiofauna keeps other parasitic organisms in check. The beginning of the video shows a picture of a hawksbill turtle while talking about loggerheads, very jarring.  Then about how it is reported that there is more of a biome at the tail end of a loggerhead turtle's shell.  Anybody who knows anything about loggerhead turtles should know that they sleep by wedging themselves under things, thus scraping their carapace to the thickest point, first on the way in, then as they push out, so, of course there is more sessile growth on the tail end.

This will probably get buried, but I have two questions about this:
1) is it possible that one of the reasons that there are more things living near the rear of the shell could be due to more food availability due to... certain discharges?
2) couldn't wiping a turtle's shell clean actually hurt it the same way sanitizing your gut bacteria could hurt a human? I'd think it irresponsible of the researchers to just clean a turtle shell in its entirety without checking for symbiotic relationships first.
